title: Beerwizzard
author: Beerwizzard
content: Hey there!The main question is in the thread subject. I have found a new DeFi app quidi.finance that claims to bring up to 321% API by staking your funds in their concentrated liquidity protocol. The website looks ok, you can even deposit funds and claim staking rewards. However, the overall lack of info regarding the project creates some doubts.Anyone got any thoughts on this matter?

comments.author: mk4
comments.body: Unless you can read the smart contract code, it's best that you stay away from small, lesser known protocols.But if you want to take the risk, go ahead. But use a separate Ethereum wallet since you're going to be connecting your wallet to the protocol and you'll be confirming (potentially malicious) transactions that could potentially empty up your entire wallet.

comments.author: OmegaStarScream
comments.body: Their site mentions that the protocol has been verified by multiple auditing firms, but nothing links to the audit. There's also no mention of any auditing in their Twitter page. So as mentioned above, it's probably not worth the risk and you shouldn't be fooled by the founders sharing a picture of their faces either.

comments.author: Bitcoin_Arena
comments.body: 364% APR, too good to be true... LolNot sustainable at all, where are they going to get all that money to pay people up.The domain is even still so new according to whois. I wouldn't trust this one.QuoteDomain: quidi.financeRegistrar: NameCheap, Inc.Registered On: 2023-05-04Expires On: 2024-05-04Updated On: 2023-05-31And here is a classic one ----> "If you don't understand where the yield is coming from, you are the yield."

comments.author: TryNinja
comments.body: The APR doesnâ€™t mean anything if you can only earn it by staking a shitcoin. You buy $1000 of ShitcoinXyz and stake it. Before earning even 10% over that amount, the coin crashes and your $1000 investment is now worth $100. Did the high APR matter? No!

comments.author: PX-Z
comments.body: That doesn't differ from ponzi scheme returns. How those companies can earn by giving that kind of return. Even the businesses that offer smaller returns haven't survived and files bankruptcy, about this one maybe they will just go away knowing they're just new.

comments.author: noorman0
comments.body: It's just their version of the best-of-confidence bid, but it's not really a new scheme to predict that they'll find a point of failure. I just ignore them with the story of several defi companies that failed last year because they offered benefits beyond reasonable limits.Objectively, their site is unconvincing at first glance.

comments.author: vv181
comments.body: Quote from: Beerwizzard on June 26, 2023, 05:10:38 PMThe website looks okThe website looking neat does not guarantee the site is not a scam or shady. Making a good website is pretty easy nowadays, especially since there are already a lot of templates with such kind of UI.Quote from: Beerwizzard on June 26, 2023, 05:10:38 PMyou can even deposit funds and claim staking rewards.It also does not tell completely if it is safe from any illegitimate things.Quote from: Beerwizzard on June 26, 2023, 05:10:38 PMHowever, the overall lack of info regarding the project creates some doubts.Anyone got any thoughts on this matter? Absurd APY? Check. Recently registered domain? Check.Source Code/smart contract information not visible? Check.A lot of red flags. Even if it is legit, the APY is simply not feasible. Note also, the audit information, if they have truly done the audit, the transparency reports should be publicly available. Merely claiming they have done an audit is meaningless.

comments.author: Beerwizzard
comments.created_time: July 09, 2023, 04:07:00 PMLast edit: July 12, 2023, 03:23:24 PM by Beerwizzard
comments.body: Well, I was curious enough to try this protocol and I have successfully managed to withdraw my tokens (staked funds have 10d cooldown). However, it still seems that the project is fraudulent and they are trying to get some fat before the exit scam.Quote from: OmegaStarScream on June 26, 2023, 06:18:25 PMTheir site mentions that the protocol has been verified by multiple auditing firms, but nothing links to the audit. There's also no mention of any auditing in their Twitter page. So as mentioned above, it's probably not worth the risk and you shouldn't be fooled by the founders sharing a picture of their faces either.I have decided to make a small research on this direction and asked the audit firms for confirmation.
